newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks end up on plastics and electronics.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks end up on plastics and electronics.

text.p: Late buying in plastics pushed Taiwan share prices to a slightly higher close on Saturday, brokers said. Electronics again performed strongly as well.
The benchmark index ended up 24.52 points or 0.29 percent at 8,367.46, off an intraday high of 8,436.00.
Turnover was a heavy T$152.2 billion.

Plastics surged 5.27 percent as buying emerged after leading maker Nan Ya Plastics rose by the daily seven percent limit to T$82.5. "Investors are afraid electronics might have risen too much so some have turned to plastics, which had lagged recent gains," said Ben Lee of Nomura Securities.
China Petrochemical also was limit up to T$45.5.
Taiwan's trendsetting electronics shares remained investors' favorite, rising 1.11 percent. Chipmaker United Microelectronics rose T$3.5 to T$89.
Top chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor surged T$7.5 to T$135 after saying on Friday its May sales rose 16 percent from April, though they were still 16.1 percent below May 1996.
"Buying continues to focus on Taiwan Semiconductor, which will go ex-bonus issue on June 12, as its sales are expected to recover significantly in the second half," Lee said.
Financial and construction shares fell, somewhat offsetting Saturday's gains.
Brokers said they expected a firming trend, with the broad index testing resistance around 8,500-8,600 points.
For next week, a 8,200-8,600 trading range was seen.
The market is closed on Monday for a national holiday.
